cern.extjfx.chart.data

Class LinearDataReducer<X extends Number,Y extends Number>

  • java.lang.Object
    • cern.extjfx.chart.data.LinearDataReducer<X,Y>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DataReducer<Number,Number>

    public class LinearDataReducer<X extends Number,Y extends Number>
extends Object
implements DataReducer<Number,Number>
    Implementation of the DataReducer that reduces a large data set to the number of visible pixels
    • The algorithm goes through the data along the X axis from xMin to xMax. It typically merges the value of several original points into two pixel value, by picking the minimum and maximum Y value from the original data.
    • The original data can have "holes", i.e. no data points between two X values. In this case, the algorithm interpolates data in between.
    • If the size of the data set is smaller than the number of pixels, it is not reduced. The resulting "reduced" data therefore contains the same number of points as the original, which may be fewer than the pixels.
    Author:
    Stephane Bart Pedersen, Vito Baggiolini

    • Method Detail

      • reduce

        public List<XYChart.Data<Number,Number>> reduce(ChartData<Number,Number> data,
                                                Range<Double> dataRange,
                                                int maxPointsCount)
        Description copied from interface: DataReducer
        Reduces the number of data points to be equal or less than specified maxPointsCount.
        Specified by:
        reduce in interface DataReducer<Number,Number>
        Parameters:
        data - data to be reduced
        dataRange - range of data (lowerBound and upperBound) from which given data should be reduced
        maxPointsCount - the maximum number of points that the reduced list should contain
        Returns:
        list containing reduced data, with maximum maxPointsCount elements

      • reduce

        public List<XYChart.Data<Number,Number>> reduce(double[] xIn,
                                                double[] yIn,
                                                double xMin,
                                                double xMax,
                                                int width_scene)
        Algorithm that actually does the work.
        Parameters:
        xIn - x-axis input data (original), must have the same length as yIn
        yIn - y-axis input data (original), must have the same length as xIn
        xMin - lower bound of data to be reduced, given in original x units. By default this is the first value of xIn, i.e. xIn[0]
        xMax - upper bound of data to be reduced, given in original x units. By default this is last value of xIn, i.e. xIn[xIn.length-1]
        width_scene - in pixels = number of points the reduced data shall have
        Returns:
        list containing reduced data, with maximum width_scene elements
